unnormalised: ## Navigating the Healthcare Maze: My Adventures with IDs
normalised: navigating the healthcare maze: my adventures with I-Ds

unnormalised: So, last month, my grandma, Dadi Lakshmi, needed to see a cardiologist for a checkup. She’s usually pretty sprightly for 80-something (she insists she’s still "sweet sixteen at heart!"), but she’d been complaining about some chest pain. Booking the appointment wasn’t too bad; Apollo Hospital uses a pretty slick online system. But then came the fun part – the insurance!
normalised: so, last month, my grandma, Dadi Lakshmi, needed to see a cardiologist for a checkup. she’s usually pretty sprightly for eighty something (she insists she’s still "sweet sixteen at heart!"), but she’d been complaining about some chest pain. booking the appointment wasn’t too bad; Apollo Hospital uses a pretty slick online system. but then came the fun part – the insurance!

unnormalised: Dadi Lakshmi has a senior citizen health insurance policy with Star Health, policy no. STH/2023/00789. Seems simple enough, right? Wrong. First, they needed her Aadhaar number, 9876-5432-1012, to verify her identity. Then, they asked for her Unique Health ID (UHID), which apparently is something different altogether. I didn’t even know she *had* a UHID! Turns out, it was printed on some old document from her last hospital visit – a string of numbers and letters: ABHA-123-456-7890-1234. Who even remembers these things?
normalised: dadi Lakshmi has a senior citizen health insurance policy with Star Health, policy no. S-T-H slash two thousand twenty three slash zero zero seven eight nine. seems simple enough, right? wrong. first, they needed her Aadhaar number, nine eight seven six dash five four three two dash one zero one two, to verify her identity. then, they asked for her Unique Health I-D (U-H-I-D), which apparently is something different altogether. i didn’t even know she had a U-H-I-D! turns out, it was printed on some old document from her last hospital visit – a string of numbers and letters: A-B-H-A dash one two three dash four five six dash seven eight nine zero dash one two three four. who even remembers these things?

unnormalised: And that was just the beginning! The TPA (Third Party Administrator) for Star Health also wanted her CGHS (Central Government Health Scheme) card number, since she’s a retired government teacher. That’s CGHS/2020/Delhi/12345. I was starting to feel like I was deciphering some ancient code. I mean, seriously, how many IDs does one person need just to see a doctor? It felt like every other form was asking for a different number or code.
normalised: and that was just the beginning! the T-P-A (Third Party Administrator) for Star Health also wanted her C-G-H-S (Central Government Health Scheme) card number, since she’s a retired government teacher. that’s C-G-H-S slash two thousand twenty slash Delhi slash one two three four five. i was starting to feel like i was deciphering some ancient code. i mean, seriously, how many I-Ds does one person need just to see a doctor? it felt like every other form was asking for a different number or code.

unnormalised: The poor chap at the insurance desk looked just as frazzled as I did. He explained that each ID serves a different purpose – Aadhaar for identity, UHID for a centralized health record (supposedly!), CGHS for her government benefits, and the insurance policy number for, well, the insurance policy itself. It still felt incredibly redundant and confusing.

unnormalised: I started wondering if there’s a better way to manage all these healthcare identifiers. Maybe a single, universal ID linked to all our health information? Or at least, a system that’s easier for us common folk to understand. It's all so overwhelming, especially when you're already stressed about a loved one's health.

unnormalised: Anyway, after what felt like an eternity of paperwork and ID-number-wrangling, we finally got Dadi Lakshmi checked in. Thankfully, the cardiologist said her heart was strong as an ox (her words, not mine!), just needed a bit of medication and some rest. But the whole experience left me thinking – surely there’s got to be a simpler, less ID-intensive way to navigate India's healthcare system! Here’s hoping for a smoother process next time.
